prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our integration time request is driven by the requirement to detect the absorption signature of HCO+ with S/N=3 in the Magellanic Stream (MS), and is described below. We first estimate the integrated CO line flux in the MS by adopting the typical value found for molecular clouds in the Magellanic Bridge: ~100 mK km/s (Mizuno et al. 2006, ApJL, 643, L107). We then convert from CO line flux to the expected HCO+ absorption equivalent width (EW) using the relation derived from Galactic sight lines in Lucas & Liszt (1996, A&A, 307, 237): EW(HCO+)[km/s] = 1.5 * I_CO[K km/s], giving a typical optical depth of 0.1. For a 3-sigma detection we require rms noise in optical depth of 0.033 per 1 km/s channel.
The required per-channel Band 3 sensitivity (dS) is then a function of the background source continuum flux density at 100GHz (S100), and is given by dS = 0.033 * S100. The observations have velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s per channel, which we anticipate to smooth to 1 km/s. Therefore the final rms noise estimate is dS= 0.033 * S100 * sqrt(1/0.2).

Our integration time request is driven by the requirement to detect the absorption signature of HCO+ with S/N=3 in the Magellanic Stream (MS), and is described below. We first estimate the integrated CO line flux in the MS by adopting the typical value found for molecular clouds in the Magellanic Bridge: ~100 mK km/s (Mizuno et al. 2006, ApJL, 643, L107). We then convert from CO line flux to the expected HCO+ absorption equivalent width (EW) using the relation derived from Galactic sight lines in Lucas & Liszt (1996, A&A, 307, 237): EW(HCO+)[km/s] = 1.5 * I_CO[K km/s], giving a typical optical depth of 0.1. For a 3-sigma detection we require rms noise in optical depth of 0.033 per 1 km/s channel.
The required per-channel Band 3 sensitivity (dS) is then a function of the background source continuum flux density at 100GHz (S100), and is given by dS = 0.033 * S100. The observations have velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s per channel, which we anticipate to smooth to 1 km/s. Therefore the final rms noise estimate is dS= 0.033 * S100 * sqrt(1/0.4).

We first estimate the integrated CO line flux in the MS by adopting the typical value found for molecular clouds in the Magellanic Bridge: ~100 mK km/s (Mizuno et al. 2006, ApJL, 643, L107). We then convert from CO line flux to the expected HCO+ absorption equivalent width (EW) using the relation derived from Galactic sight lines in Lucas & Liszt (1996, A&A, 307, 237): EW(HCO+)[km/s] = 1.5 * I_CO[K km/s], giving a typical optical depth of 0.1. For a 3-sigma detection we require rms noise in optical depth of 0.033 per 1 km/s channel.
The required per-channel Band 3 sensitivity (dS) is then a function of the background source continuum flux density at 100GHz (S100), and is given by dS = 0.033 * S100. The observations have velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s per channel, which we anticipate to smooth to 1 km/s. Therefore the final rms noise estimate is dS= 0.033 * S100 * sqrt(1/0.4).

Our integration time request is driven by the requirement to detect the absorption signature of HCO+ with S/N=3 in the Magellanic Stream (MS), and is described below. We first estimate the integrated CO line flux in the MS by adopting the typical value found for molecular clouds in the Magellanic Bridge: ~100 mK km/s (Mizuno et al. 2006, ApJL, 643, L107). We then convert from CO line flux to the expected HCO+ absorption equivalent width (EW) using the relation derived from Galactic sight lines in Lucas & Liszt (1996, A&A, 307, 237): EW(HCO+)[km/s] = 1.5 * I_CO[K km/s], giving a typical optical depth of 0.1. For a 3-sigma detection we require rms noise in optical depth of 0.033 per 1 km/s channel.
The required per-channel Band 3 sensitivity (dS) is then a function of the background source continuum flux density at 100GHz (S100), and is given by dS = 0.033 * S100. The observations have velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s per channel, which we anticipate to smooth to 1 km/s. Therefore the final rms noise estimate is dS= 0.033 * S100 * sqrt(1/0.4).
This source is a well known ATCA point source calibrator, so observing a separate phase calibrator is unnecessary. Moreover, we don't care about the absolute flux calibration - we are just measuring fractional absorption against the continuum level, whatever it may be - so it's not necessary to include a flux calibrator either. However, there is a known bug in OT that causes the "User Defined Calibration" to crash. According to the answers to HelpDesk ticket #4564 on 07:07 PM of Dec 2nd "We have discovered a possible OT bug affecting validation of user-defined calibration requests. We are working on it and I will update you as soon as possible. Meanwhile if you want to go ahead and get your proposal past validation you could accept the observatory standard calibration and just describe in the technical justification form the details of the user-defined calibration that you wish to use. If the bug does not get fixed in time for you to update your proposal the issue will be handled properly at the review stage if you have fully described in your TJ form ." The total time should be much less than the time estimated by ALMA Observation Tool.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to measure the molecular fraction of the Magellanic Stream, the closest example of a gaseous accretion stream, to constrain the formation rate of molecular hydrogen in low-metallicity environments and resolve microphysical gas properties leading to star formation. Recent studies show that the Stream contains rich atomic hydrogen structure with highly patchy and weakly-excited molecular gas, suggesting that absorption-line spectroscopy will provide the best observational constraints on its molecular abundance. We propose to search for absorption lines from HCO+, HCN, HNC and CCH in the direction of 14 radio continuum sources known to be bright at 100 GHz. We require high sensitivity (optical depth<<1), and ALMA, even in its current phase, is the only instrument that can accomplish this. The detection of dense gas tracers like HCO+ in the Stream would imply the existence of a significant cool-gas reservoir and would have huge implications for the mass and evolution of the Magellanic System, as well as provide important clues about molecular content and star formation in the first galaxies in the Universe.
